courseDescription: An introduction to the various media, techniques, styles, content, and contexts in the visual arts as they are manifested in the world's cultures.
Technical and Digital Skills: Digital art tools and software proficiency
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing different artistic styles and content
Critically evaluating cultural contexts of art
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading artistic endeavors in a group setting

courseTitle: Honors: Introduction to the Visual Arts
courseDescription: An introduction to the various media, techniques, styles, content, and contexts in the visual arts as they are manifested in the world's cultures. Open only to students in the Honors College.

This course provides an opportunity to discover, appreciate, and acquire broad knowledge of art history through the ages, from the Prehistoric era to contemporary times within a global perspective. Students will learn to examine and critically analyze major forms of artistic expression from diverse cultures and periods of art in order to understand their individual and collective contributions to the arts.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with peers on art research projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Comparative analysis of art styles across cultures and time periods
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on art history topics

courseDescription: Special topics in art history.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of art historical research
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of art historical texts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on art history topics

courseDescription: This course covers the art and architecture of the ancient world from its Paleolithic origins to the end of antiquity and the birth of Christian art. Ranging from drawings in caves to mosaics in churches, the material addressed in the course is situated in its social, political, and historical context. The objective of this course is to provide a visual and cultural literacy of ancient art and to familiarize students with the methods, theories, and traditions upon which ancient art history is grounded.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion facilitation on ancient art topics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of ancient art information
Identification of artistic traditions and methods
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in art history research
Leading discussions on ancient art topics
Coordinating group projects in art analysis

courseDescription: This course is an effort to confront conspiratorial thinking where art is concerned. The interpretation of human visual culture – particularly from ancient periods – is a particularly subjective endeavor, but in recent years social media have accelerated the proliferation of baseless theories about art, architecture, and material culture. From alien-builder theories to simple misconceptions about the polychromatic nature of Classical art, these pseudoarchaeologies can be found throughout the world, but they tend to harangue and ultimately undermine non-European peoples and cultures and their cultural heritage.
Technical and Digital Skills: Critical analysis of art theories and interpretations
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engaging with diverse perspectives in art history
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and disproving false narratives in art history
Analyzing the impact of misinformation on cultural heritage
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on debunking art myths
Organizing research materials efficiently for fact-checking

courseDescription: “Early Modern” is a relatively new term applied to a broad period of artistic production in Europe that encompasses distinct, yet overlapping, style periods, which include the “Renaissance,” “Baroque,”  “Rococo,” and “Neoclassicism.” This course will examine painting, sculpture, architecture, and graphic arts in Europe from 1400—1800 within the context of artistic creativity in relationship with intellectual, religious, economic, political, scientific, and cultural changes and developments in the Western world.
Technical and Digital Skills: Artistic techniques in painting, sculpture, and graphic arts
Architectural styles and structures in Europe from 1400-1800
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with peers on art analysis projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of art in the context of intellectual, religious, economic, political, scientific, and cultural changes
Identifying artistic influences and developments in European art
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on Early Modern art movements

courseDescription: A study of selected art history topics to be specified in the class schedule each semester. May be repeated for credit as topics vary.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of art pieces, Research skills in art history, Interpretation of historical context
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for research deadlines, Group collaboration for class discussions

courseDescription: This course explores the art and architecture of ancient Egypt from the migrations of anatomically modern humans out of Africa to the persistence of Egyptian identity under Roman domination. Egypt looms large in the popular consciousness of modern society, with extraterrestrial or magical connotations. This course encourages critical thinking skills by stressing the importance of evidence and context in the interpretation of Egyptian monuments and iconography. Fulfills non-western requirement for majors.
Technical and Digital Skills: Art and architecture analysis of ancient Egypt
Interpretation of Egyptian monuments and iconography
Understanding Egyptian identity under Roman domination
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation of evidence and context in art analysis

courseDescription: The contributions of women in the various fields in the visual arts--painting, graphics, sculpture, architecture, and the crafts.

courseTitle: 15th and 16th Century Art in Northern Europe
courseDescription: The painting, sculpture, and graphics of the Netherlands, France and Germany in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries with discussion of artists such as Jan van Eyck, Hieronymus Bosch, Pieter Bruegel the Elder, and Albrecht Durer.
Technical and Digital Skills: Painting techniques of the 15th and 16th centuries
Knowledge of graphic design in Northern Europe
Identification of artistic styles of Jan van Eyck, Hieronymus Bosch, Pieter Bruegel the Elder, and Albrecht Durer
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Participation in group discussions on art history
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of symbolic meanings in artwork
Comparative analysis of different artists' styles

courseDescription: This course is a survey of High Renaissance Art in Italy (roughly 1473 to 1520), focusing on the recognized major artists or 'masters' of the High Renaissance, Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, Raphael, and Titian, as well as their lesser known contemporaries.
Technical and Digital Skills: Artistic techniques of Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, Raphael, and Titian
Knowledge of art history and styles of the High Renaissance period
Understanding of color theory and composition in art
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with peers on art projects
Effective communication of artistic ideas and concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying influences and themes in High Renaissance artworks
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for art exhibitions or showcases

courseTitle: Mannerism and Late Renaissance Art in Italy
courseDescription: The works of Leonardo, Michelangelo, and Raphael brought the Renaissance to its height, but by 1520, two of these masters were dead. It is in this aftermath - post-1520 - that a new generation of artists arose revolutionizing the art world. This course is a survey of mid-late sixteenth-century art in Italy.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of art techniques used by Leonardo, Michelangelo, and Raphael
Understanding of art history in the mid-late sixteenth century in Italy
Ability to analyze and interpret art styles and movements
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussing and presenting art concepts and ideas
Collaborating with peers on art analysis projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critically evaluating art pieces and styles
Identifying influences and innovations in art during the post-1520 period
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on art history topics

courseTitle: Baroque Art in Italy and Spain
courseDescription: This course is a survey of Baroque Art in Italy and Spain. Material includes painting, sculpture, and architecture of the seventeenth and early eighteenth centuries, with discussion of artists such as Caravaggio, Annibale Carracci, Gian Lorenzo Bernini, Francesco Borromini, Diego Velazquez, Jusepe de Ribera, and Francisco de Zurbaran, among others.
Technical and Digital Skills: Artistic techniques in Baroque painting, sculpture, and architecture
Understanding of Baroque artistic styles and influences
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and analysis of Baroque art with peers
Presentation of research findings on Baroque artists
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpreting symbolism in Baroque art pieces
Comparative analysis of different Baroque artists
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Curating virtual exhibitions of Baroque art
Leading group discussions on Baroque art movements
Organizing research projects on specific Baroque artists

courseDescription: This course is a survey of Baroque Art in Northern Europe. Materials include painting, sculpture, and architecture of the seventeenth and early eighteenth centuries, with discussion of artists such as Peter Paul Rubens, Rembrandt, Vermeer, and Poussin, among others.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of art history in Northern Europe
Ability to analyze paintings, sculptures, and architecture from the seventeenth and early eighteenth centuries
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective discussion and presentation of Baroque art concepts
Collaboration with peers to analyze and interpret artworks
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of Baroque art pieces
Identifying artistic influences and styles in the works of artists like Rubens, Rembrandt, Vermeer, and Poussin
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing research materials on Baroque art
Leading group discussions on specific artworks or artists

courseDescription: A critical study of the formal, cultural, and intellectual developments of the graphic design discipline, including related activity in fine art, illustration, and industrial design. This is a writing intensive course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Graphic design software proficiency (e.g., Adobe Creative Suite)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective writing skills for analyzing and interpreting design history
Presentation of research findings in a clear and concise manner
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of historical design movements and their impact on contemporary graphic design practices
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Prioritization of research tasks for writing-intensive assignments
Time management for meeting course deadlines

courseDescription: Examines the major historical developments in the decorative and applied arts, landscape design, and material culture from the Renaissance to the Modern period.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of historical art styles and movements
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of historical research findings
Ability to collaborate with peers on projects related to decorative arts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of art pieces and their cultural significance
Identification of trends in decorative arts over different historical periods
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Curating and organizing exhibitions of decorative arts
Leading discussions on the importance of material culture in historical contexts

courseTitle: American Art and Architecture, 1600 to the Present
courseDescription: Through the study of form, content, and context of selected works of painting, architecture and sculpture made in colonial North America and the US from the 17th to the 20th century, this course will probe changing American social and cultural values embodied in art. Students will study individual artists as well as themes, with particular attention to the production and reception of art in a developing nation, the transformation of European architectural styles into a new environment, the construction of race in ante- and post-bellum America, and the identification of an abstract style of art with the political ascendancy of the US after World War II.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating on research projects with peers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating the impact of social changes on artistic expression
Interpreting the transformation of European styles in American art
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on art history topics
Organizing research materials and sources effectively
Managing time to complete research projects

courseDescription: Survey of the mainstreams of European art during the late eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, including discussion of architecture, sculpture, painting, and the graphic arts.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with peers on art analysis projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpreting historical context in art pieces
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on art movements

courseDescription: An examination of the development of photography as a scientific curiosity, a tool for artists, and as a fine art in itself from the early nineteenth century to the present day.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Historical context explanation to diverse audiences

courseDescription: An introductory course to the history of gardens. Gardening is explored as an artistic expression and connections are made to other visual arts such as painting, sculpture and architecture, as well as to as theater and public representation. The course combines a heavy site-visiting component with readings and individual research directed towards the final course paper and presentations.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with other artists and designers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying connections between different art forms and garden design
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on garden history and artistic expression

courseDescription: A study of the international movements in visual arts and design in the interwar years from Dada to the New World's Fair.
Technical and Digital Skills: Digital art tools and software proficiency
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with other artists and designers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of art and design concepts
Interpretation of surrealistic and utopian themes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in art and design

courseDescription: An intensive study of the two decades when modernist styles and theories in art, design, and architecture were codified and challenged internationally.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding modernist styles in art, design, and architecture
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engaging in critical discussions about art history
Collaborating on group projects in art analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critically evaluating modernist art and design concepts
Identifying challenges to established artistic theories
Developing innovative perspectives on art movements
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on art theories
Organizing research materials on modernist styles
Facilitating group projects in art analysis

courseDescription: A study of the analysis, theoretical approaches, methodologies, and effects of the practice of art criticism. This is a writing-intensive course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Digital media analysis in art criticism
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective writing skills for art critique
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying different theoretical approaches in art criticism
Analyzing the effects of art criticism on the art community
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing writing-intensive assignments in art criticism
Leading group discussions on art analysis

courseDescription: An investigation of past and present approaches to scholarship in art history.  Students participate in a series of writing assignments designed to strengthen their research and writing skills, culminating with the presentation of original research in oral and written form. This is a writing intensive course.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with peers on research projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of art historical sources

courseDescription: Lectures and critical discussion of the development and configurations of the various styles emergent since 1960, both in America and Europe.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engaging in critical discussions on postmodernism
Collaborating with peers on postmodern theories
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critically evaluating postmodern texts and artworks
Identifying themes in postmodern cultural developments

courseDescription: An unpaid, structured work experience in a museum, gallery, archive, or related environment for credit. Criteria for evaluation will be determined by work supervisor and cooperating faculty advisor. May be repeated for credit.  Available for pass/fail grading only.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with colleagues and supervisors
Team collaboration in a museum setting
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project planning and execution for museum exhibits
Coordinating with different departments within a museum
Taking initiative in completing assigned tasks

courseDescription: A specialized field activity outside of the classroom. Qualifies as a CAP experience. Available for pass/fail grading only.

An extracurricular activity approved for credit based on objectives, criteria, and evaluative procedures as formally determined by the department and the student prior to the semester in which the activity is to take place.  Such credit is subject to review by the provost.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Conflict resolution in a group setting

courseDescription: An extracurricular activity approved for credit based on objectives, criteria, and evaluative procedures as formally determined by the department and the student prior to the semester in which the activity is to take place.  Such credit is subject to review by the provost.
A study of selected topics in art history to be specified in the class schedule each semester. May be repeated for credit as topics vary.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of art historical sources

courseDescription: A study of selected topics in art history to be specified in the class schedule each semester.  May be repeated for credit as topics vary.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilizing digital archives for art research
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Participating in group discussions on art topics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and interpreting art historical texts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group projects on art history topics

courseDescription: Before Dalí…before Magritte…before De Chirico, there was Hieronymus Bosch. Well before the advent of the Surrealism movement in the twentieth century, the late fifteenth-century/early sixteenth-century Dutch painter Hieronymus Bosch rocked the art world with his fantastical, disturbing, and enigmatic paintings.  This course will critically examine Bosch and his work. Students will work like detectives, first by dismantling long-standing misinterpretations about Bosch’s work, then by analyzing and deciphering his iconography through the lens of the period in which he lived, including art theory, politics, religion, devotion, and alchemy, among other topics.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of art analysis findings
Collaboration with peers in art research projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of art theories and interpretations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on art analysis
Organizing research materials and findings effectively

courseDescription: This course examines the life, sculptures, paintings, and architecture of one of the greatest Italian Renaissance artists, Michelangelo Buonarroti.
This course examines the life and revolutionary paintings of the Italian Baroque painter Caravaggio.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analyzing and interpreting historical art pieces
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with peers on art analysis
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time effectively for art research

courseDescription: Venice is set apart from other cities in Italy and from Europe not only by its geography—a city seemingly floating on water, with canals instead of streets—but also by its unique history, traditions, and cultural identity. The consideration and examination of its mythical origins in the fifth century, through its history as a territory of the Byzantine Empire, and the establishment of their Republic in 1297, this course will examine how Venice fashioned its own identity through its art and architecture during the Italian Renaissance.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion facilitation on myths and legends

courseDescription: This course will examine the ways in which prevailing ideas about women shaped visual imagery, and in turn, how these images influenced, perpetuated, and even changed perceptions about women from the fifteenth through seventeenth centuries in Italy (Renaissance and Baroque periods). Students will explore how text and visual imagery informed one another, and closely examine works of art by women artists, commissioned by women patrons, and works featuring women through thematic topics. Although patriarchy dominated the Renaissance and Baroque periods, the course will recover the histories of women artists, patrons, and writers, and examine how women navigated the gender oppression of their periods to reclaim their power and value.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion facilitation on gender roles in art
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of gender representation in art
Identifying societal influences on women's portrayal
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on women's empowerment in art

courseDescription: This seminar is an exploration of the visual and material culture of Pompeii, incorporating a broad spectrum of evidence, ranging from the city’s temples to the wall paintings in the city’s brothels. The goal of the class is to instill a working knowledge of the most recent scholarship on the ancient city and to contextualize Pompeii's art and architecture in the historical narrative of the city and the broader body of scholarship on Roman cultural history.
A survey of the aesthetic, technological, and social forces that transformed international architecture in the 18th and 19th centuries.
Technical and Digital Skills: Architectural design principles of the 18th and 19th centuries
Drawing and drafting techniques in architecture
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with peers on architectural projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing architectural styles from the Romantic era
Critically evaluating the impact of social forces on architecture
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing timelines and deadlines in architecture

courseDescription: An examination of the architecture, planning, and related design of the twentieth and twenty-first centuries around the globe.  Special emphasis is placed on the formation of the international style between the world wars and its disintegration in the recent past. This is a writing intensive course; the course also satisfies the general education impact of technology requirement.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of building materials and technology

courseTitle: Realism in Modern and Contemporary Art
courseDescription: This course examines the changing motivations, contexts, and characteristics of realist art since the inception of modernism. While definitions of radical and conservative have wavered and flipped, recognizable imagery seems always to function as a critical intervention within aesthetic racial, or gender-based hegemonies. As students examine numerous artists’ strategies, they will see that reality isn’t always so easy to pin down.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpretation of artistic intentions and contexts

courseDescription: Anxiety about painting’s purpose and relevance are woven into modern art’s linear concept of history. The goal of this class is to help students understand, both intellectually and emotionally, the ambitions that motivate painting, as well as to give them an opportunity to sample the diverse practices and critical approaches that make up the painterly landscape, and finally to examine how or if it fits within the broader scope of contemporary art.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of own work and others

courseDescription: This course is a collaborative exploration of the problems and opportunities of national and international public art that combines the practical with the theoretical, and the studio with the art-historical.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of installation tools and techniques
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with stakeholders and communities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of public art impact and reception
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project planning and coordination for public art projects

courseDescription: The research and writing of a thesis on an advanced topic in art history to be determined by the student in concert with a faculty advisor. The thesis option is intended for art history majors preparing for graduate study in the field, and serves as the required culminating work for their degree.
Technical and Digital Skills: Advanced topic exploration in art history
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of art historical information

courseDescription: A study of selected topics in art history to be specified in the class schedule each semester. May be repeated for credit as topics vary.
A study of selected topics in art history to be specified in the class schedule each semester. May be repeated for credit as topics vary.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of art history topics

courseDescription: Independent research on a topic to be selected under the guidance of a faculty advisor. Course is restricted to art history majors.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting research findings to peers and faculty
Collaborating with other art history majors
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of art historical sources
Identifying gaps in existing art historical research
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for independent research projects
Taking initiative in selecting research topics
Leading discussions in art history seminars

courseDescription: Independent research on a topic to be selected under the guidance of a faculty advisor. Course is restricted to art history majors.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation of research findings to peers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of art historical sources

courseDescription: Before Dalí…before Magritte…before De Chirico, there was Hieronymus Bosch. Well before the advent of the Surrealism movement in the twentieth century, the late fifteenth-century/early sixteenth-century Dutch painter Hieronymus Bosch rocked the art world with his fantastical, disturbing, and enigmatic paintings. Bosch’s contemporaries and modern scholars have deemed his art as the product of both his madness and genius. This course will critically examine Bosch and his work. Students will work like detectives, first by dismantling long-standing misinterpretations about Bosch’s work, then by analyzing and deciphering his iconography through the lens of the period in which he lived, including art theory, politics, religion, devotion, and alchemy, among other topics.
This course examines the life, sculptures, paintings, and architecture of one of the greatest Italian Renaissance artists, Michelangelo Buonarroti.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team coordination for complex artistic projects

courseDescription: This course examines the life and revolutionary paintings of the Italian Baroque painter Caravaggio.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation of art historical research findings

courseDescription: Venice is set apart from other cities in Italy and from Europe not only by its geography—a city seemingly floating on water, with canals instead of streets—but also by its unique history, traditions, and cultural identity.  The consideration and examination of its mythical origins in the fifth century, through its history as a territory of the Byzantine Empire, and the establishment of their Republic in 1297, this course will examine how Venice fashioned its own identity through its art and architecture during the Italian Renaissance.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion facilitation on myths and traditions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on Venice's history

courseDescription: This course will examine the ways in which prevailing ideas about women shaped visual imagery, and in turn, how these images, influenced, perpetuated, and even changed perceptions about women from the fifteenth through seventeenth centuries in Italy (Renaissance and Baroque periods). Students will explore how text and visual imagery informed one another, and closely examine works of art by women artists, commissioned by women patrons, and works featuring women through thematic topics. Although patriarchy dominated the Renaissance and Baroque periods, the course will recover the histories of women artists, patrons, and writers, and examine how women navigated the gender oppression of their periods to reclaim their power and value.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engaging in group discussions on gender roles in art
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing visual imagery for hidden meanings
Interpreting the impact of patriarchal norms on art creation
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing research projects on women artists
Leading discussions on reclaiming women's history in art
Organizing presentations on women's empowerment in art

courseDescription: This seminar is an exploration of the visual and material culture of Pompeii, incorporating a broad spectrum of evidence, ranging from the city’s temples to the wall paintings in the city’s brothels. The goal of the class is to instill a working knowledge of the most recent scholarship on the ancient city and to contextualize Pompeii's art and architecture in the historical narrative of the city and the broader body of scholarship on Roman cultural history.
A survey of the aesthetic, technological and social forces that transformed international architecture in the 18th and 19th centuries.

courseDescription: An examination of the architecture, planning, and related design of the twentieth and twenty-first centuries around the globe.  Special emphasis is placed on the formation of the international style between the world wars and its disintegration in the recent past.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with multidisciplinary teams in design projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation of design principles in different cultural contexts

courseTitle: Realism in Modern and Contemporary Art
courseDescription: This course examines the changing motivations, contexts, and characteristics of realist art since the inception of modernism. While definitions of radical and conservative have wavered and flipped, recognizable imagery seems always to function as a critical intervention within aesthetic racial, or gender-based hegemonies. As students examine numerous artists’ strategies, they will see that reality isn’t always so easy to pin down.

Anxiety about painting’s purpose and relevance are woven into modern art’s linear concept of history. The goal of this class is to help students understand, both intellectually and emotionally, the ambitions that motivate painting, as well as to give them an opportunity to sample the diverse practices and critical approaches that make up the painterly landscape, and finally to examine how or if it fits within the broader scope of contemporary art.
